replies.text: Imagine the gains youd make if you simply didnt invest in companies with scandals or sour sentiment.

BABA is up 25 over the past year while VOO is up 38 so thats not the success story youre making it out to be. Success in the market isnt just making a profit. If youre not beating the SP then youre losing. Bear in mind that while youre sitting on cash waiting for the next piece of bad news, that money isnt appreciating like it would with a set it and forget it approach. Also every time one of your picks starts to plateau and you decide to sell you have to give the tax man his cut which means you have less to reinvest. If you have to sell before youve owned the stock for a year then youll have to pay capital gains which will cut into your profit even more. All these things plus the fact that there isnt a guarantee that a stock will bounce back from bad news means that this is probably not the slam dunk you think it is. You may get lucky a few times but its probably not a sustainable investing strategy.

The comparison between Costco COST and CrowdStrike CRWD based solely on their forward PE ratios 50x for COST and 75x for CRWD and PEG ratios above 3 ignores key differences in their business models, growth trajectories, and market dynamics. Costco COST operates as a highvolume, lowmargin retailer. It has a stable, predictable cash flow, massive scale, and significant pricing power. The retail sector traditionally trades at lower multiples due to its lower growth potential compared to tech. CrowdStrike CRWD is a highgrowth cybersecurity company with a SaaS model. Its in a fastgrowing sector with a strong demand for cybersecurity, especially after recent highprofile breaches. Its high multiple reflects its future growth potential rather than current earnings. Based on the overvaluation of the market as you pointed out, plus intrinsic value vs value of the SP at 4080 depending on the metric you use, Buffet Indicator at 175 adjusted for inflation, equities should not be the priority for investing in this environment. yields bouncing around so quickly, the market is caught between worrying about inflation and worrying about recession. ratios SPYTLT, SPYGLD, etc. are showing the market is concerned with safe haven investments. the geopolitical issues, election year, debt ceiling in Jan. 2025 The obvious strategy as we see the market implementing is rotation into consumer staple equities, bonds, tbills, cash, KMLM, etc. Gold is useful but overvalued so that has to be factored in. Tom Lee of fundstrat recently noted the SP minus the mag 7 has a PE of 18 and at current rates, treasuries have an effective PE of 25. In other words, if a company is not growing and doesnt need to grow, it can return all of its earnings as dividends and outperform treasuries. Some companies do this and even let earnings go negative before cutting 5 dividends. Some people say that treasuries and the dollar are bombproof and safe investments, but that is not always true, especially regarding some of the points you made. You have to put your money somewhere, because the dollar hasnt gone up in value for a very long time, but trust me that gold and crypto are not safe havens if there is a real growth scare and market crash down the road and Ive been through many. Some of the mag 7 have good forward PE ratios, some will have higher forward PE ratios unless they can turn earnings around. I personally dont bet that a company is just about to turn the corner with the next report, even if marketunderperforming analysts are optimistic, but bet that fundamental growth trends will continue until there is evidence to the contrary. I would certainly agree that some stocks are overvalued, but that is always true. Right now, I think a lot of dubious nongrowing software and plebian semi stocks have caught AI tailwinds when they probably wont benefit from all the demonstrably increasing spend on transformer GPUs and ASICs. With your overbought metrics, you should remember that in a bull market, things can stay overbought for years, the same years you should be in the market. But, I am sitting on 20 cash right now, which is the most in the last two years, hoping to deploy it this month. In addition to lots of electionrelated uncertainty around the world, and typical geopolitical risks, Im nervous about Israels response to Iran because the military leaders are making really ominous noises. Their proxy war has been ugly, but not nearly as ugly as it could be. Irans leaders could be delusional enough to launch missiles at Arab oil production and rain a lot more missiles down on cities than they have so far. In this case, Im not betting on cooler heads to suddenly prevail, because escalation is the apparent trend. Ill be glad if Im wrong, having missed out on some gains by briefly holding insurance and dry powder, but any appreciable selloff is an entry point for me. Over the next two years, I think interest rates are coming down. If they dont, economic and earnings growth will probably be the culprit, which is probably fine for stocks. It doesnt make sense to me for the Fed funds rate to be higher than the inflation rate for long periods of time, and it is right now. Stocks will crash in the future, but they will crash when companies dramatically decrease spending, which hasnt happened yet. Let me know when that happens. In a recession, companies cut spending by a lot, and the percent increase in unemployment and decrease in household spending usually doesnt compare. I think the scariest crashes happen when interest rates are low, because the Fed doesnt have as much ammo, and companies are more likely to have loaded up on debt that they think they can cheaply finance, until they cant.

afaik, there are only 3 lawsuits actually filed thus far. One is on behalf of investors, with a single plaintiff, one is on behalf of 3rd parties inconvenienced by flight delays, with 3 plaintiffs. A third was filed on Monday 0819 but unknown if an investor or 3rd party. Docket numbers for Texas Western District Court are 124cv00857, 124cv00881, and 124cv00954, respectively. afaik, there are no client lawsuits so far, and Delta have not yet filed. Personally, I dont believe the two filings Ive read so far have much merit. Crowdstrikes earnings report is Wednesday after the bell, so its likely to be a bit of a roller coaster next week. The nature of the outage doesnt amount to the severity of a hack IMO. For example, you get a security system for your house, it gets hacked and someone breaks in and steals all your valuables. Here, the system failed to do the one thing its supposed to do. If that same system malfunctioned, locking you out of your house, sure thats also a big problem but at the end of the day, your valuables were still protected. So while yes, there were costly, global impacts to operations, this wasnt a largescale data lossbreach which Id argue has a bigger impact to reputation and operations than the outage. I personally dont think this kind of mistake ever happens again, and this incident shined a spotlight on weaknesses in organizations ability to execute effective contingency plans to remain operational

Going to redirect to ChatGPT because it will answer the question in far more detail than I ever could The behavior youre describing aligns with what some people refer to as swing trading, which involves holding a stock for a short period days to weeks to capitalize on expected price movements. Its different from day trading, where traders buy and sell stocks within the same day, often executing multiple trades in a single day. Many retail investors might buy and hold stocks for short or long periods based on their strategy, market outlook, or financial goals. When you see people talking about buying, holding, or selling specific stocks, they could be Day Traders Buying and selling stocks within the same trading day to profit from small price fluctuations. Swing Traders Holding stocks for a few days to weeks, aiming to profit from shortterm market movements. LongTerm Investors Buying and holding stocks for months or years, focusing on the companys growth or dividends rather than shortterm price changes. Your plan to buy a stock and sell it after a couple of weeks fits more with swing trading. Many people engage in this type of trading to get a taste of the market or to try and make shortterm profits. If you proceed, keep in mind the following Transaction Costs Ensure the potential profit is more than the trading fees, if applicable. Tax Implications In a taxable brokerage account, selling a stock within a year could subject you to shortterm capital gains tax, which is typically higher than longterm capital gains tax. Market Risk Stock prices can be unpredictable in the short term, and your expected profit might not materialize. If this approach appeals to you, youre not alonemany people test the waters of the stock market this way.

Most organizations worldwide that have competent IT operations were fixed before business hours in the morning. The ones that are whining they took 9 days Delta to recover are exposing their own negligent architecture and operations. The time to reset servers and systems is a choice made by every organization based on how they design them and how they provision or skimp on resources. If Delta took 9 days to fix a nonhack, nonissue that needed only a safe reboot step, imagine how poorly they would do on an actual malicious hack, data breach, code integrity or other actually serious issue. Deal with an earthquake at your main IT office? Find out your production system is full of foreign actor corruption? If they crapped the bed just on a simple safe reboot operation, it means they have zero resilience and zero contingency plans in place.

The media has been significantly misrepresenting the Crowdstrike updates. The PIR indicates significant, industrylevel testing for both sensor and cloud releases. The file that broke the host machines was not code per se in the classic sense it didnt change the software installed on the machine but rather it was more equivalent to a config file. I can guarantee that most companies ship similar config files to their hosts without testing. Its A LOT of work to add staggered publications for every file possible associated with a product. In an everyday sense, its almost similar to how journalists dont necessarily fully proofread their documents before sending them to their editors. If a file reader the editor used happened to have a bug that couldnt read the file correctly, the software breaks. In this case, it had devastating consequences but not because of negligence that differed from the industry standard, but rather because of a bug they didnt fully prepare for. All software has bugs and bugs make it out to production every day. Any publishersubscriber system is extremely hard to test in a staggered fashion. Have you noticed that test amber alerts are sent to EVERYONE, rather than just a couple of phones? Sending out config files typically doesnt follow the classical software validation system of canaries and test environments. You just have subscribers that receive it and you hope that the code that reads the messages correctly processes it. It sounds like Crowdstrike is indeed currently implementing systems where these files are rolled out in a staggered fashion, but its not going to be a simple process. Sounds like theyre going to become one of the companies with the highest standards of QA in the industry after this event.

Its because Delta relies more heavily on Microsoft products than United and American. Delta runs the best operation because of all the data it feeds these systems, and they are all protected by Bitlocker

What sucks is that media and judges and juries wont understand how none of that is Crowdstrikes fault. Weve seen it from day zero of this saga. Even here on Reddit, where at least some of the kiddos should know better, were awash in comments about Crowdstrike deserving to go bankrupt, UberEats memes, Musk cultists endorsing his call to rip out their cyberprotection.

None of that is Crowdstrikes fault. I think thats a little too far in the other direction. They are still the ones that toppled the first domino. But you are right that I have no clue how any judge or jury or anyone really decides what percentage is appropriate. You need to have deep knowledge of IT distributed systems, law, finance, air travel...

None of OPs 4 points are Crowdstrikes fault, theyre the fault of the customers own IT. In civil law theres a concept that youre only responsible for what you caused that could not be mitigated. So if bump into your fence and scratch the paint, then Im responsible for fixing the scratch. But if you leave the damage unfixed, and then the wood rots, and you fail to deal with that, and then the fence topples onto your dog house, and then you dont do anything about that either and eventually the dog house gives way and squashes your dog, well under the law Im not responsible for your dog, your dog house or your fence. Im only responsible from for the initial scratch, and whatever is is reasonable to cure that specific harm. You have whats called a duty to mitigate, which means taking action to make sure the scratch doesnt lead to other consequences. Thats precisely the concept at play here. Crowdstrike was responsible for the initial issue. If a customer lost money or incurred costs during the 2 hour initial period before Crowdstrike issued the workaround instructions, thats fair. If a customer had to pay someone overtime, or a minimum 4 hour call out charge. Or travel and expense, those are in bounds. But beyond that, it shifts to customers duty to mitigate. If they couldnt or wouldnt reboot for 9 days, thats on them, not Crowdstrike.

Your hypothetical involves deliberately ignoring the issue. I shouldnt need to have paint on hand to immediately fix a scratch that shouldnt have happened in the first place. If you drive drunk and kill someone in an accident, you dont get off Scott free because they werent wearing a seat belt. Like youre basically advocating nobody should be held responsible for any computer problem, since a perfectly designed system should have redundancies in place to mitigate any failures. Company negligently ships a hard drive that fails? Guess its not their fault, should have used RAID. USEast goes down for 12 hours because Amazon let an intern directly push to prod? Should have regional replication and fail over.

replies.text: This is why I dont look at returns for anything on less than a 5 year timeline. 9 months during a booming market is a terrible metric when evaluating investments.

Selling naked puts will work right up until it zeroes out your account or worse dont pick up pennies in front of a steamroller. With respect you should not be selling options unless you actually know what youre doing with heding and risk management. It can go fantastically wrong very quickly. If you want an alternative to vegas or the lottery, buying options can be fun for some people who arent professionals but certainly dont stake any more than youd be fine losing.

Selling covered calls is a conservative strategy that is expected to reduce both risks and returns, compared to just holding the underlying asset. The seller will probably see lots of small wins get the premium and keep the stock a few large losses get the premium and have to sell the stock at a below market price that will more than offset the wins. Both strategies are likely to make money buying holding is likely to make more. Check the returns of any ETF that uses this strategy compare them to the returns of the assets they own youll see this.

I generally dont buy options except as a hedge. I dont bet on future price direction but I do try to profit off the premium created by those who do. This is not selling naked calls, the risks are definably limited. When I sell puts, its always against a stock I would want in my portfolio and in quantity and price my portfolio can afford if put. Could it go to 0? Sure, any stock could, but that doesnt make it Vegas. I have been put stock on occasion, then my cost basis is lower than the outright purchase of the underlying stock would have been. If the stock price is above strike at expiry, I pocket the premium and move on. I have a common position in LRCX today i was put from 2018 that is up 5x my base price, which includes the premium I sold back then. And, yes, the position was under water at the time, as it would have been had I purchased the stock. In this case, in the long run, I made out way better than whoever put me the shares of this phenomenal company.

I am a long term investor with decades of experience and held a Series 7 decades ago, straight out of college BS Econ. If i get put on the common, its generally in one I want to take a position in or add to. If the price runs up and away, I am rewarded with the premium. I win either way, i never get too far out over my skis on this strategy and it represents single digit percentages of my equity positions, which are mostly LT.

Again, with covered calls, the issue is not that the seller is likely to lose money. The issue is that theyre likely to make less money than they would by buying holding the same assets. The premiums are not magic free money, despite what some claim.

but I dont trust that investment strategies such as DCA work on individual stocks so much as they work on ETFs. As long as you can buy fractional shares of individual stocks it works. The key to dollar cost averaging is being able to buy fractional shares so the full amount of the equal periodic payment is used to buy the security, with no leftover money uninvested. Dollar cost averaging began with mutual funds, which are always sold as fractional shares. x200B and I dont know if its wise doing my personal in SP as well Nothing wrong with going all index funds in all of your accounts, especially if you have a history of being lured into making illadvised individual stock picks. However, if you like investing in individual stocks, as do I, I made a spreadsheet of 134 dividendpaying SP 500 index stocks that have beaten the SP 500 index since 1993 or since the stocks IPO if it was after 1993. Since these are dividendpaying SP 500 stocks they are unlikely to behave like some of the duds you picked in the past, but past performance doesnt guarantee future results, blah blah blah. Have fun looking through the spreadsheet, I found some hidden gems in there.

An advisor can help you do a lot more than just transact for you. They will learn your investor profile which is your interests, your goals and your sensitivity to risk. Yeah, pretty sure. BTW, do you believe strongly in DCA? Ive recently read some articles that said that DCA is worse in the long run than lump sum investing. I will never do a lump sum, but that got me thinking on DCA

Since the stock market goes up over the long term, the sooner you get the money into the stock market lump sum the longer it has to grow. But it doesnt go up in a straight line. It can easily drop 10 or more in the months after you lump sum, which can be discouraging. In addition, despite the recent drop we are closer to recent highs than to recent lows, so I wouldnt lump sum in now. I think regular small purchases over the next 612 months would be easier on the nerves, and the small amount of possible additional gain by lump sum investing now isnt worth the risk.

Valuations matter over the long run, but shortterm, its all positioning and flows. To borrow an analogy from Cem Karsan, when youre on a jetliner, you dont really care how far off the ground you are valuation so long as the engines are still firing positive flows. When the engines cut off, how far off the ground you are is all that matters. Markets also take a lot longer to top than to bottom, largely because a lot of people see the valuation problem and try to short while flows are still positive. If you cant get involved in the trend, fine at least dont fight it. Better to wait for the dominant flows to turn negative before shorting a good trader hopes only to catch the middle of the move.

The macromacro economic gameplan moving forward looks clear. Productivity growth has stalled out in every developed economy in the world. Every developed economy save for SK is broke off its ass in terms of debt to GDP. Between demographic shortfalls, resource shortages, pollution, etc, there are no serious prospects for growth rates to catch back up. What future catalyst or technology will make the world more productive in 10 years than it is today? Chatbots? Every developed nation is thus pretty much bankrupt, and is implicity defaulting via currency inflation. Thats why stocks are running, and will keep running for a while. Any cashflowing asset that can keep up with inflation, is going to get pushed up with inflation. And I think inflation is going to be very persistent. Nothing lasts forever, and one day this trend will break down. My guess is what breaks it will be a major European sovereign debt crisis by around 2030. Think France going down rather than Greece. Productive capital will flee Europe, likely to America, and bond buyers will shit themselves and start demanding higher yields from already desperately broke governments. Where we go from there, I dont know. I really want to see how the whole growth goes up forever meme blows up and unwinds in the 21st and 22nd centuries, but Im not going to live long enough to see it all through. Ill just be around to catch the early innings.

I used to be head of front office of a large bank of all trading desks. I started work in 99. What you call earnings, for us, was just investors relations IR telling us what the shareholders wanted their EPS to be as you can before filing a paper to the regulator simply modify your earnings to what the shareholders wanted. EPS is just an easily modified variable with no meaning. Check Truist Financial they sold a fire sale tactic aka drop your most profitable entity to ensure that even tho your dead in the water you still show inflated earnings. But you didnt earn anything. OP is holding bags. The techniques they use to protect the system are the simpliest ... mainly blacklists and whitelists. Thats ignoring XDRs machine learning, behavioral analytics, device protection profiles, the fact that you can ingest firewall alerts into XDR, etc. Oh wow you can completely bypass AV as an admin!? You know what else you can do as an admin, uninstall the AV software. BlackHat speaker was basically farming career karma for explaining how a product works, which good for him, probably looks great on his resume. NGAVs. They all work relatively the same. They all rely on MITRE techniques tactics and procedures along with IOCs to blockalert on bad behavior. The idea that one company has secret sauce when malware has relied on many of the same fundamental software vulnerabilities for decades is rediculous and I will die on that hill. I have used both CS and XDR. Both have pros and cons.

The threat model might be limited yeah but again to me its just an example of how poor ONE of their product is, think about the rest if they build stuff this way. Cortex literally showing you what regex it uses to prevent you from executing a command? Like how they dont know you shouldnt show this info? All of configuration files in plain sight that basically reveals the internals of the product.

Their PANOS has a long history of being a source of vulnerabilities that were exploited You can say this to all companies selling appliances NetApp, HPE, Cisco, Juniper, Check Point,... The thing is they all run Linux bundled with lots of ancient packages that have CVEs showing ups all the time. Enterprises and security pentest shops perform scanning regularly plus monitor CVE database, once anything shows up theyll turn their attention to appliances they own and publish reports. Not to say their stock is overpriced or not, I no longer follow this market closely.

Customer and revenue means that they are good at selling it and their product is good. You dont get to their level without a good product. One vulnerability in a module that represents 10 of their revenue is not enough to predict a market change. Again, youre just shilling S and its super clear.

OP is not wrong in his DD though, he also didnt say he know the play for PANW, so I see no harm here. Im not an AI or endpoint Security expert but I guess even with AIbased engine, the model still need to be updated regularly to deal with new malwares behavior. Otherwise, it will cause a lot of false negative.

I am holding bags because I did my DD and came up with a thesis I believe in, not the other way around. I did not randomly buy S and then started searching to confirm any bias. I do not deny PANW and CRWD are market leaders now, but I do not believe they will keep that spot forever and Im making a bet on who I think is going to be next up there. Do not misinterpret this as SELL ALL YOUR CRWD PANW!!! BOOO THE END IS NEAR kind of thing. CRWD and PANW are profitable companies now with solid fundamentals, but their success is rooted in an era that is coming to an end in my opinion. Another thing I didnt mention is that I want to capture the massive growth a small cap stock as S can provide, a growth that CRWD and PANW cant provide because their growthexpansion phase is done.
Im not surprised though, they didnt start as an endpoint security company lol

I figured you were new, thats okay. Try to learn as much as you can about options before you waste your cash. There is a metric to options, several actually, but one in particular called implied volatility IV for short. Iv plays a factor into options price, and iv is driven by expected events that would drive market price. Earnings is a big one, dates of known contract announcements or company announcements. The market knows all of this and tracks it through IV. The closer you get to these events, the IV will rise, causing the price of an option to rise with it. So by buying options for known events as far away from them as you can stomach, the cheaper you can get that same option for. You have to balance that with how much you think the price will change before that event though. Options are simple yet complicated. So if you buy an option today for earnings tomorrow, it will likely be as expensive as that option gets. Starting the moment the event happens, the iv begins to drop dramatically, lowering the price of the option. This is known as iv crush if you have heard that term used.

People who know what they are talking about never and I mean never just say page fault by itself, unless they are referring to the process of accessing virtual memory behind the scenes which is the almost universal context. If you meant a program generating an unhandled exception leading to a segfault, due to accessing memory they werent given access to by the OS, then anyone who knows what they are talking about, prepends invalid to page fault. But even then thats not really the language anyway, you sound like a noob. Heres a protip about yours truly. I never, ever, talk about anything unless I have checked my facts first. If you have ever done any Windows systems programming which I have and its obvious you havent, you would know they universally use that specific language in their kernel error codes. This is the error message from the Crowdstrike outage The PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA bug check has a value of 0x00000050. This indicates that invalid system memory has been referenced. Typically the memory address is wrong or the memory address is pointing at freed memory Source one of many and just the first hit I found Full list of BSOD error codes showing they exclusively use the language PAGE_FAULT when describing these cases This again shows your lack of even basic readinglanguage skills as an invalid page fault would be a doublenegative in this context and imply a valid access to memory. The correct usage would be A critical page fault kernel error is an invalid reference to system memory. Whereas an invalid page fault in a nonpaged area would be a valid reference to system memory. Im guessing you are so clueless that you dont understand the context of a PAGE FAULT has a different meaning when used in kernel error codes referencing nonpaged memory vs describing a page fault due to attempting to access virtual memory that has been swapped to disk. And these are logged as well as informational error codes. Ill add that a BSOD is desired behavior in this case as you dont want a bad kernel driver writing to random pages as that would lead to data corruption which is way worse. Second no, running in kernel space is not required. Running in user space and communicating with an OSprovided service running in kernel space made for that purpose, is the much safer albeit marginally slower way to do it. You are the posterboy for the DunningKruger Effect as you have just transparently telegraphed to me that you have literally zero experience working on forensic investigations involving APT threat actors or even have any experience working with NextGen EDR clients. Including specifically Crowdstrike, as they in particular do not market to zeroes like yourself. You dont know what the software actually does because you have never used it. First of all, Crowdstrike isnt exclusively an antivirus product. It operates as a kernel mode rootkit by design, as it can be configured to log extensive system information about all running processes. Such system calls, disknetwork access, etc. Second, you are absolutely, 100 correct that Microsoft could expose a safe usermode API to allow a system process running as Administrator to access all the same information. However, there is a big problem with that because the bad guys in general and APT actors in particular will write kernelmode rootkits that not only can trivially evade usermode detectionlogging, they can actively spoof systems calls and replace error codes see StuxNet for example. So instead of disabling the usermode EDR product which could be detected, they could hijack it and inject whatever they want via their kernel rootkit. So do shut up already with your droning claims of expertise already and go get a macbook, it will protect you from running thirdparty stuff in kernel mode by default. I think you need that. Already have one and I hate to break it to you but the vast majority of InfoSec peeps run nix. Either OsX or Linux. I have a windows gaming laptop, which is fine, but I dont use it for anything other than entertainment.

P/E Ratio is pointless when the profit margin is increasing and sales are growing. Think about it Sales = Earnings / Profit Margin so Earnings = Sales * Profit Margin. If both factors rise at the same time, the earnings growth is multiplicative and non-linear (potentially exponential if the demand is rising while prices are also rising similar to what happened to Apple). Thus, you can't use a linear valuation metric like P/E Ratio to measure a non-linear change in earnings. Of course, there are many implied ways to obtain valuations, but why in the world would I tell you that.

Here is a rundown of policy differences. This is not an endorsement.Mr. Trump recently stated that he supports reducing the top corporate income tax bracketfrom 21% to 15% in order to help companies like CRWD to compete strongly against foreigncompetitors. 7 years ago, Mr. Trump spearheaded reducing the rate from 35% to 21%.Ms. Harris proposes increasing the top corporate rate from 21% to 28%, a 25% increase inincome tax CRWD would have to pay instead of investing in it's growth.Mr. Trump wants to maintain the current long-term capital gains tax on sales of CRWD stockat 15% and 20% for higher earners.Ms. Harris proposes taxing capital gains taxes as ordinary earnings. So an investor in the 28% marginal income tax bracket would see in increase in capital gains taxes on CRWD stock sales from 15% to 28%, almost doubling the tax owed. Ms. Harris also proposes, with Mr. Biden,to impose the tax on "unrealized" gains, on CRWD stock that an investor owns but has not yetsold. The unrealized gain tax would be imposed on higher earners.Mr. Trump lowered personal income tax brackets across the board in 2017. Those reductions will "sunset" (end) in 2025 if they are not renewed. Mr. Trump wants to renew them. Ms. Harris avoids the subject, but Mr. Biden has expressed disdain for the 2017 reductions. The increased standard deduction would also sunset. If the brackets sunset and increase to the pre-2017 levels, so too would the cap-gains tax with Harris's proposal.

Here are my thoughts: The COO of Delta was let go, and it's not surprising given the situation. Having 50,000 remote servers out of physical reach and beyond the immediate control of IT staff is a poor practice and something I've never encountered in my experience managing systems. It seems like a case of some IT professionals engaging in questionable practices without proper oversight.The real challenge is dealing with CEOs who are skilled at deflecting blame to justify their positions. Blaming Microsoft was a desperate move. CrowdStrike (CRWD) will likely have to take most of the blame since they can't fault their customers. Typically, the COO is responsible for approving the staffing budgets for the CIO, while the CIO usually seeks approval for large capital expenditures directly from the CEO.CRWD might need to offer discounts on services, but they're unlikely to lose many customers. Palo Alto or any other host-based solutions are generally more cumbersome and inefficient to deploy on live systems compared to CrowdStrike. I can't imagine trying to implement Palo Alto's host-based services on over 50,000 hard-to-manage systems—it's just not practical.As for the upcoming earnings, it's uncertain what will happen. However, in the long term, I'm not worried about CRWD. Most analysts believe the stock has already bottomed out. Best of luck to all CRWD longs!

I'm not sure that asking folks on a message board is the best place to get advice as folks are likely to "talk their book".That said, deciding when to sell may have less to do with a stock and more to do with you as an investor or trader.  Ask yourself the following:What is my holding timeframe?  Weeks/months/years?What is my risk tolerance?  Am I able to tolerate large swings in share price?Do I make decisions objectively, or do I tend to be ruled by my emotions?If you find yourself in need of frequent emotional reassurance in order to feel OK about owning a stock, I would advise either reducing the position size or selling it for that reason alone.  It's likely a sign that the stock does not fit well with your personal risk tolerance.I fully expect CRWD to reach and surpass 380 within 2 years, but it won't be a straight line getting there.  The earnings call on 8/28 will undoubtedly have an impact one way or another as investors look carefully at what the company says about customer subscriptions and forward guidance. I suggest you read the Root Cause Analysis report now out on CrowdStrike's website.  Get help from someone with technical expertise if you need help understanding it.There was no gross negligence here.  The update was tested via a normal robust test suite across many Windows variants and workloads.  The error encountered by some customers did not show up in their tests, including product-level ones.  The error simply slipped through a testing gap.  All software vendors are susceptible to serious errors sometimes slipping out due to the complexity of software and the inherent finiteness of human and computing resources.

Firing one or more staff may not be constructive if the primary source of the problem is determined to be related to overall testing and/or release infrastructure rather than the immediate direct cause of the error in the code.Software and testing infrastructure for products as broad and complex as the Falcon suite are maintained by many hands.  Testing infrastructure in particular is the result of a history of many decisions made by multiple people and teams over many years for a company of CrowdStrike's size.Based on the preliminary incident report, the release of a serious error seems to be the compound effect of multiple deficiencies in the testing and release infrastructure plus the interaction of software components likely maintained by different teams.  Latter is a conclusion drawn by the observation that kernel-level coders are unlikely to also maintain file content validators for content being downloaded from a server to a client.There is plenty of blame to go around, and it's hard to see how firing a few specific individuals would improve matters unless there is clear gross negligence with respect to an individual's area of responsibility.  From the outside this appears to be more a shared failure caused by the complexity of multiple interacting systems within the company maintained by multiple teams, some of whom may rarely have direct interaction (if at all).CrowdStrike's final incident report may reveal more information at whatever point it becomes available.

Having worked in more than a dozen software organizations over three decades, I can assure you that gaps like this exist in virtually every software product or tool.Developing rigorous test suites takes a lot of time, and this activity often gets short-changed at some point during the development cycle.  About the only project I've heard of that might be an exception to this is the flight control software that was used on U.S. space shuttles.  However, that team operated under an extremely process-heavy development process that no commercial software vendor I've worked for has the patience for.  This includes my experience at one vendor whose core product was 30+ years old and had a very mature codebase.Based on CrowdStrike's preliminary incident report, it is clear that the software update passed their normal testing process.  However, one uploaded file contained invalid content.  It had passed the content validation suite, but in their incident review they discovered a gap in the test suite that the error slipped through.It's not entirely clear from the above preliminary report, but the way the error manifested may not always be repeatable.  If this were true, it might help to explain how the error got past other types of product tests.  It crashed the Windows kernel due to a memory read error, and these often can be hard to reproduce or detect.They messed up, but not as badly as you might think.

Lawsuits and class actions will be an issue for at least a year, and they may be subject to GDPR fines (up to 4% of global revenues) due to the incident limiting access to personal data.

Beyond that, no executive wants to be the one who bought it if they cause another incident and things go down. 

The ones who do buy it will negotiate things like stricter SLAs, better liability language, and termination for convenience. CRWD will accept these terms because they have no other choice.

Their best sales people and engineers will leave, seeking safe harbor in a storm. This leakage of experience, institutional knowledge, and culture will echo throughout the company and amplify all of their struggles.

Sales are going down, liabilities are going up, their corporate insurance premiums will rise substantially, and they have absolutely no margin for error -- one more incident and they are done.

I'd never cheer for folks to lose money or a company to go belly up, I am just calling it like I see it and the odds seem stacked against them.
